segment.source: Boot from a DVD
segment.target: Boot from a DVD

segment.source: Boot from a DVD
segment.target: Boot from a DVD

segment.source: Boot from a DVD
segment.target: Boot from a DVD

segment.source: The simplest way to install Windows on new hardware is to start directly from the Windows product DVD by using an answer file that is named Autounattend.xml.
segment.target: The simplest way to install Windows on new hardware is to start directly from the Windows product DVD by using an answer file that is named Autounattend.xml.

segment.source: This method provides flexibility when network access is not available or when you are building only a few computers.
segment.target: This method provides flexibility when network access is not available or when you are building only a few computers.

segment.source: You can use this same method to build an initial image in an image-based deployment scenario, typically known as a master installation.
segment.target: You can use this same method to build an initial image in an image-based deployment scenario, typically known as a master installation.

segment.source: By using the answer file, you can automate all or parts of Windows Setup.
segment.target: By using the answer file, you can automate all or parts of Windows Setup.

segment.source: You can create an answer file by using Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM).
segment.target: You can create an answer file by using Windows System Image Manager (Windows SIM).

segment.source: For more information, see Create or Open an Answer File.
segment.target: For more information, see Create or Open an Answer File.

segment.source: Prerequisites
segment.target: Prerequisites

segment.source: To complete this walkthrough, you need the following:
segment.target: To complete this walkthrough, you need the following:

segment.source: An answer file on removable media (CD or DVD-ROM) or a USB flash drive.
segment.target: An answer file on removable media (CD or DVD-ROM) or a USB flash drive.

segment.source: The answer file must be named Autounattend.xml.
segment.target: The answer file must be named Autounattend.xml.

segment.source: The answer file must be located at the root of the media.
segment.target: The answer file must be located at the root of the media.

segment.source: A Windows product DVD.
segment.target: A Windows product DVD.

segment.source: To install Windows from the Windows product DVD
segment.target: To install Windows from the Windows product DVD

segment.source: Turn on the new computer.
segment.target: Turn on the new computer.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: This example assumes that the hard disk drive is blank.
segment.target: This example assumes that the hard disk drive is blank.

segment.source: Insert both the Windows product DVD and the removable media that contains your answer file into the new computer.
segment.target: Insert both the Windows product DVD and the removable media that contains your answer file into the new computer.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: When you use a USB flash drive, insert the drive directly into the primary set of USB ports for the computer.
segment.target: When you use a USB flash drive, insert the drive directly into the primary set of USB ports for the computer.

segment.source: For a desktop computer, this is typically in the back of the computer.
segment.target: For a desktop computer, this is typically in the back of the computer.

segment.source: Restart the computer by pressing the CTRL+ALT+DEL keys.
segment.target: Restart the computer by pressing the CTRL+ALT+DEL keys.

segment.source: Windows Setup (Setup.exe) starts automatically.
segment.target: Windows Setup (Setup.exe) starts automatically.

segment.source: By default, Windows Setup searches at the root of a drive and other locations, such as removable media, for an answer file that is named Autounattend.xml.
segment.target: By default, Windows Setup searches at the root of a drive and other locations, such as removable media, for an answer file that is named Autounattend.xml.

segment.source: This occurs even if you do not explicitly specify an answer file.
segment.target: This occurs even if you do not explicitly specify an answer file.

segment.source: For more information, see “Implicitly Searching for an Answer File” and “Implicit Answer File Search Order” in Windows Setup Automation Overview.
segment.target: For more information, see “Implicitly Searching for an Answer File” and “Implicit Answer File Search Order” in Windows Setup Automation Overview.

segment.source: After the Setup program is finished, validate that Windows applied all customizations, and then reseal the computer by using the sysprep command together with the /generalize option.
segment.target: After the Setup program is finished, validate that Windows applied all customizations, and then reseal the computer by using the sysprep command together with the /generalize option.

segment.source: The Sysprep tool removes all system-specific information and resets the computer.
segment.target: The Sysprep tool removes all system-specific information and resets the computer.

segment.source: The next time that the computer starts, your customers can accept the Microsoft Software License Terms and add user-specific information.
segment.target: The next time that the computer starts, your customers can accept the Microsoft Software License Terms and add user-specific information.

segment.source: Optional: To automatically run the Sysprep tool after the installation, set the Microsoft-Windows-Deployment | Reseal component setting in your answer file (Autounattend.xml) as follows:
segment.target: Optional: To automatically run the Sysprep tool after the installation, set the Microsoft-Windows-Deployment | Reseal component setting in your answer file (Autounattend.xml) as follows:

segment.source: Optional: To run the Sysprep tool manually from a running operating system, type the following at a command prompt:
segment.target: Optional: To run the Sysprep tool manually from a running operating system, type the following at a command prompt:

segment.source: For more information, see Sysprep (System Preparation) Overview.
segment.target: For more information, see Sysprep (System Preparation) Overview.

segment.source: Next Steps
segment.target: Next Steps

segment.source: This walkthrough illustrates a basic unattended installation that requires no user input.
segment.target: This walkthrough illustrates a basic unattended installation that requires no user input.

segment.source: You can manually add more customizations to the newly installed operating system.
segment.target: You can manually add more customizations to the newly installed operating system.

segment.source: If this is a master installation or an installation that you will use for image deployment, shut down the computer.
segment.target: If this is a master installation or an installation that you will use for image deployment, shut down the computer.

segment.source: Then, capture an image of the installation by using the Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) tool or any third-party imaging software.
segment.target: Then, capture an image of the installation by using the Deployment Image Servicing and Management (DISM) tool or any third-party imaging software.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: You must run the sysprep /generalize command before you move a Windows image to a new computer by any method.
segment.target: You must run the sysprep /generalize command before you move a Windows image to a new computer by any method.

segment.source: These methods include imaging, hard disk duplication, and other methods.
segment.target: These methods include imaging, hard disk duplication, and other methods.

segment.source: Moving or copying a Windows image to a different computer without running the sysprep /generalize command is not supported, even if the new computer has the same hardware configuration.
segment.target: Moving or copying a Windows image to a different computer without running the sysprep /generalize command is not supported, even if the new computer has the same hardware configuration.

segment.source: Generalizing the image removes unique information from the Windows installation so that you can apply that image on different computers.
segment.target: Generalizing the image removes unique information from the Windows installation so that you can apply that image on different computers.

segment.source: The next time that you boot the Windows image, the specialize configuration pass runs.
segment.target: The next time that you boot the Windows image, the specialize configuration pass runs.

segment.source: During this configuration pass, many components perform actions that must occur when you boot a Windows image on a new computer.
segment.target: During this configuration pass, many components perform actions that must occur when you boot a Windows image on a new computer.

segment.source: For more information, see How Configuration Passes Work.
segment.target: For more information, see How Configuration Passes Work.
